description:
Electrona antarctica, also known as the Antarctic lanternfish, is a species of small mesopelagic fish found in the Southern Ocean surrounding Antarctica. It belongs to the family Myctophidae, commonly referred to as lanternfishes.

The Antarctic lanternfish is a small, slender fish with a characteristic bioluminescent photophore (light-producing organ) pattern along its body. It typically ranges in size from 4 to 8 centimeters in length. Like other lanternfishes, E. antarctica possesses a series of photophores that emit light, which is believed to play a role in communication, camouflage, and other ecological functions.

This species is a significant component of the Southern Ocean's midwater ecosystem, serving as an important prey item for larger predatory fishes, seabirds, and marine mammals. E. antarctica feeds primarily on small crustaceans, such as copepods and euphausiids, as well as other planktonic organisms.

The distribution of E. antarctica is closely tied to the Antarctic Circumpolar Current and the cold, nutrient-rich waters of the Southern Ocean. It is considered a key indicator species for monitoring the health and dynamics of the Antarctic marine ecosystem.
